column1: math for real “when will I ever use this?”

The U.S. Postal Service (USPS) allows companies to ship packages with a length plus girth measurement that is less than 108 inches. The length of a package is its longest side; the girth is the measurement around the thickest part of the package (perimeter or circumference) that is perpendicular to its len gth (see the diagram). To ship the largest volume of product using the fewest boxes, it is ideal to determine the dimensions that maximize the volume of the box for a given length plus girth.

Edited by Erik Tillema, etillema@iupui .edu, who teaches at Indiana University in Indianapolis, and Fred Dillon, dillon 314@sbcglobal.net, a math educator from Strongsville, Ohio. Manuscripts should show how math is used to solve a real-life problem, preferably in the context of one’s profession, and should be no more than 300 words. Submit manuscripts through http://mtms.msubmit.net.
